pros: you get to talk to people
cons: you dont get any breaks available

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good experience for those interested in starting in the mental health field in a psych or social work role.
cons: The earning potential drops significantly for those interested in mental health work but not educated at the masters level, but the workload is significantly higher than your peers who will earn more but are typically less educated.

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Decent option for people living with SPMI who have no other options 3 meals per day for clients Individual Case Management available
cons: Feels like being in high school again-- The direct support staff only care about themselves (they're all quite young or just out of college). Not patient-centered.

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Minneapolis, MN
cons: repetitive tasks, disconnected management, lack of personal space

review_title: A lovely well fun facility with smart, diverse, caring staff
pros: Staff is excellent, compassionate, inclusive. Residents are enjoyable to be around, they understand boundaries thanks to multiple staff with consistency. Staff goes above and beyond to care for residents. Everyone takes a break together whenever possible. Lots of camaraderie which helps diffuse much of the stress. Staff is extraordinarily kind. Work starts on time and ends on time. Management staff does all they can to support their team. When mistakes are made, it is handled with intelligence, teaching and patience.
cons: The regular staff knows where everything is on their floor including the special needs of each resident. A floater needs more than 10 days to get to know the system and function safely. When training with a different person each time, a trainee ends up with lots of inconsistencies with what they are taught. Med pass is confusing and arduous until a person gets to know residents and their med regime. There are often meds missing, one key passed between staff to search for missing meds.

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good pay, generally helpful and friendly coworkers, free meals, active and changing environment, staff are good people who want to help residents, get experience in mental health field, see how SPMI actually affects people’s lives, learn a lot of new skills
cons: Insufficient break time, insufficient training, demanding workload, big nursing component (passing meds, taking blood pressures, monitoring for choking), frequently understaffed, dealing with emergency situations, very activating to my own mental illness symptoms, often felt unnoticed or unappreciated by supervisors

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Minneapolis, MN
pros: good people work here and everyone is supportive

review_title: Would recommend this job if someone is getting their foot in the door to psychiatric care
pros: The residents are what makes this job so great
cons: The nursing work is more administrative than the job description
The pay is lower than most other nursing jobs

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
If you're reading this, you're probably fresh out of college, and you just interviewed at Andrew Residence. You're a little put off by the iffy neighborhood, and you're scared of people with mental illness.

Take the job.

This is a rare opportunity to work in health care where almost everyone is committed to the patients, and not profit. It's a great way to learn more about mental health, and if you aren't all gushy over the residents in a few months, well, it's not for you. Good, supportive managers, the ability to be creative and to have real responsibilities. If you're at all thinking about nursing school, doing a year or two here will put you far beyond the majority of your classmates. If you're thinking about social work, or any kind of career in mental health, this is a fantastic place to start. 

Also, they're able and willing to be more flexible than some other workplaces. That is important. Oh, and free lunch
cons: Well.... the pay's not the greatest, but as said, you'll enjoy your time here and learn A. LOT.

pros: The staff are wonderful and very friendly! The residents are friendly as well once you get to know them! ANdrew does a great job at providing education and in-services as well!
cons: It is not in a good part of Minneapolis and can be scary at times. There are occasional fights between residents which can be nerve wracking and the TR usually ends up driving the resident to the hospital when needed. Parking is also difficult!

pros: I live and work part time at Andrew residence all health care are covered I have worked for five years in my present position.
cons: in order to move out I must have a position outside of Andrew  and I can only work part time and I may not make over 1,030.00 per month .
